body.p: If we are testing an alternative hypothesis of Ha: p ≠ p0, which of the following test statistics will give the smallest p-value?

response.feedback: Incorrect. For the choices given, this is the test statistic with the largest p-value. The data's p-hat is only half a standard deviation below p0. So it is very likely that p-hats from random sampling will be located more standard deviations away from p0 than the observed data. This likelihood is measured by the large p-value.
Incorrect. For Ha, p ≠ p0, the larger the test statistic in magnitude, the smaller the p-value.

Correct. If z = −2, the data's p-hat is 2 standard deviations below p0. So it is very unlikely that p-hats from random sampling will be located more standard deviations away from p0 than the observed data. Hence the small p-value. Click here to see this illustrated using the distribution of z-scores.

part.hint: Think about p-value as an area under the normal distribution of z-scores. If the area is small, what does this say about the magnitude of the z-score that summarizes the data?
These graphs illustrate the p-values for the z-scores given.
The z-score with the greatest magnitude will have the smallest p-value.
